Main pool and rooftop pool both cold but very welcome in 105 degrees (September) and surrounding loungers very comfortable. Great Clarins spa - around £30 - £40 for 50 min massage. No complaints about restaurants (food good - average between £35 - £40 for 2 with a bottle of wine). Lounge areas nicely decorated and very comfortable. From our experience staff were very friendly and polite even with our minimal French.    Perfect location for the main square and souks and other main sites within walking distance - just watch the traffic which comes from any direction!    Overall we thought the hotel was a good 4*. Had a great time.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Title: Lovely Hotel- An Oasis in the heart of Marrakesh-Great Location!
Review_Text: We stayed at the Jardins for three nights. Location wise you cannot get a better deal. Its about 1 minute's walk for the square that gets extremely noisy yet you walk into the jadins and leave all the husle and bustle of the streets behind you. We stayed in on of the central facing rooms facing the pool.    What we liked best about this hotel is that although poolside was busy guests were very curteous towards each other in terms of noise levels. In fact im pretty sure you could hear a pin drop in the middle of the hot days!    Staff were helpful yet it took four attempts to try and get a double bed (not just two singles lying side by side!). Eventually someone came up while we were gone and simply put a sheet over the two matresses so it seemed like a double! We gave in the end and just accepted the situation!    Other than that nothing bad about the hotel at all. Lovely quiet little haven in the centre of a busy city such as Marrakesh.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Title: An oasis of calm in Marrakech
Review_Text: We just came back from Morroco where we stayed for 5 nights at Les Jardins de la Koutoubia.  The location is excellent just a few steps from the Jemaa el Fnaa Place and the souks. You can however escape at any time from the noise and crowd in the hotel patio and just relax near one of the beautiful swimming pools.  The restaurants are nice the roof restaurant especially is delightful if a little expensive.  The rooms are very nice and big enough. The only thing we can complain about is that the medina rooms are very noisy as the windows are not holding up the noise.  So book a patio bedroom if you want to have a quiet night.  However the hotel did upgrade us for the same price in a patio room so that our stay was just perfect!  I cannot confirm any of the bad reviews on the service and certainly not on any coakroaches! The service is fine: Of course it's better to speak French but this is Morroco.  I would recommend the Jardins de la Koutoubia at any time.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with friends

Review_Text: Unfriendly front desk staff. Room smelled like old socks. 8 hours of banging from construction upstairs. Noise enters room from the courtyard in the morning.    Mandatory positive:  Lovely pool in the courtyard.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: We stayed in the hotel for 10 nights in July this year and some good and some bad experiences.    The good things... the staff were lovely we found them to be very helpful and attentive. The location is very central for the square the souks and visting the major sights. The pool (main one in the courtyard) is just lovely and a very relaxing place to lounge. The asian restraunt on the roof is fabulous.    The downsides... well for me there was one very big downside and that was the fact the hotel is obviously infested with cockroaches. We were first of all in a patio room which had door opening out onto the gardens and it was a lovely room on initial inspection in fact not sure it wasn't a suite as there was a large seating are in addition to the bedroom area... anyway at 3am on the first night I woke up with a cockroach crawling on my face!!!    To say I wasn't happy is an understatement in fact we packed then and there to leave the hotel. The next morning when we tried to check out the girl on reception called the manager after I explained why I wanted to do so.. they offered us a second floor room in the new annex of the hotel and some free spa treatments in the clarins spa. Unsure at first we asked to see the room which was a junior suite with lovely decor and very large marble bathroom. We agreed to stay after seeing it and being reassured there were absolutely no roaches in this part of the hotel. BUT they did say its a common issue in the garden rooms and they had to do onoing treatments .. and whilst we were in the new room but passing through the old part of the hotel we did see a number of dead roaches in the corridors.    So that a pretty big downside but for me the only other issue was that the new part of the hotel is quite a walk away from reception up and down over two floors and through the gardens or down a not too well lit alleyway.    I have rated the hotel neutral despite this issue as they would have got full marks from me if they didn't have an issue with roaches. As its stands I wouldn't want to book in there again as  you could not be guaranteed a roach free stay which is a very basic requirement and not too much to ask of a 5 star hotel.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: We stayed at the Koutoubia for 4 nights in April with our 10 year old son. We booked the cheapest type of room which had a window overlooking the road outside which we found quite interesting watching all the comings and goings and we did not find it noisy. The room itself was huge with a large lounge area where the hotel had made up a bed for our son and it had a large flat screen TV nicely appointed bathroom and all the trappings you would expect for this level of hotel. The room was quite hot and although the air-conditioning did seem to work it didn't really cool down the room - we asked for it to be looked at but it didn't really get any better - other people have mentioned the a/c being ineffective and I guess it would be more of a problem if the weather was very hot.    We found the whole experience of the hotel very pleasant and a really beautiful calm environment to escape from the hustle and bustle of the medina. The location is excellent as you can pop out into the heart of Marrakech and nip back after a couple of hours when the heat or haggling get too much. We chose this hotel rather than a riad as we wanted more space for our son and the benefit of the pools. We used the main pool and the roof pool and they were both rather cold and only waist deep so more for ornament and a quick cooling dip than any serious swimming. We ate in 3 of the restaurants (not the french) and found the food and service excellent. The asian restaurant on the roof is particularly lovely. The whole hotel is very tastefully decorated and there are some gorgeous rooms around the main pool area where you can sit and relax or have a drink. The undergound spa area is very stylish and provides a very relaxing ambiance but the massage I had was rather routine not helped by the fact that the masseuse didn't speak any English and my French vocabulary doesn't include many words relating to massage! The pool in the spa is deliciously warm but beware - the steps extend under the water on both sides and have very sharp edges I cut my knee swimming too close to them.    Some reviewers have complained that the staff don't speak English - what do you expect you are in Morocco! We found that the main waiting and reception staff spoke very good English and we enjoyed practicing our French with the other staff who were all very polite and friendly. I really can't understand why some reviewers have not liked this hotel - it may not have the levels of service you would find in 5* hotels in London or America but personally we had a lovely time there and would return if we ever visited Marrakech again (which we probably won't!).
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with family

Review_Title: Skip Les Jardins de La Koutoubia---not worth the time or $
Review_Text: We just returned form Morocco a few weeks ago and we must say we were very dissapointed in the hotel. Our rooms A/C did not work and we had a hard time trying to get someone to fix it.    We finally were moved (after 2 days!) to another room on a less sunny part of the hotel. We felt like we were in France as the clientele were French and the staff spoke French. Few people spoke English. We were surprised to see French women going topless especially since we were in a Muslim country. The location is near the busy square in the medina. Which may be a plus for some. But I would have definitely preferred a Riad....we stayed in many beautiful riads on our trip around Morocco with genuine Moroccan hospitality and food. This definitely did not feel like old Morocco in any way shape or form. We could have been in Europe. The birds pecking at the bread baskets at the buffet in the morning were an interesting addition. We would recommend a beautiful restaurant near the hotel but not related to it....."Nawama" gorgeous and very romantic.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: A wonderful relaxing hotel. The staff were helpful attentive but not intrusive. The spa is just delicious don't wait too long to experience it the pool alone is a secluded calming place the Hamman is just funny! The rooftop restaurant is stunning with amazing views. The whole hotel is a wonderful escape from the hectic Medina the brilliant location means no cabs and crazy driving just wander out of the souks to the tranquility of the main pool. My only advice would be to try and get a patio facing room the most noise you will get is the tweeting birds and cicadas and also possibly take a travel bath plug as they don't come as standard and shower curtains don't seem to exisit but hey for the lovely rooms with rose petals there each time the room is made up it is a small sacrifice..... we will definately return.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: I stayed in this hotel in March 2008. I had a mini suite with a large terrasse. Excellent location for this hotel. Great SPA 2 nice swimming pool. 5 great restaurants but only the snack is open for lunch.  Don't expect anything from the staff. Very poor service. Booking excursions requires extensive efforts and discussions. Very disappointing.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with family

Review_Text: Nice hotel - well sited good staff good value  Not quite real 5 star quality bit shabby no proper shower facility but it is "Maroc"!  We would go back
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Date: David H wrote a review Feb 2008
Review_Text: This hotel has a great location very close to the main square. The style of the hotel is a change from the large chain hotels and does feel tas if they have tried to have a Morrocan influence.    We had a junior suit which was spacious and kept clean. Think more high class rustic charm rather than perfect finish and the rooms should meet your expectations.    The staff where pleasant and helpful. There are plenty of nooks and cranies to hide away around the pool. And there are some good views from the roof top pool which is nicely heated.    One issue that should be pointed out is the hawkers outside the hotel who will tell you they have just finished their shift (they saw you earlier remember!). They will offer to take you to a little known exhibition (a carpet shop). They are very good at this scam so beware!

Review_Title: Delicious food, central location, but falls short of 5 star luxury
Review_Text: The four restaurants were excellent with varied choice of menus - remember to make a reservation particularly for the Moroccan and Indian restaurants. The central courtyard is beautiful with fig and orange trees as well as many rooms to sit in for reading playing board games and cards etc. One room has a fire which is lit every evening - perfect for the time of year.  We were fortunate to have above average temperatures for our stay however we were unfortunate to have a 'Medina' room overlooking the street as it was stifling and too noisy to open a window. After two requests to have our air conditioning looked at we discovered the heating is on at this time of year (February) in the hotel. So be aware that you are not booking an air/con room at this time of year!  Excursions are available from the reception - but lack any kind of information regarding itinerary or overall cost. Our four hour 'City Tour' turned into a one hour trip to a carpet shop - accompanied by Ali Babar! If heading to the Atlas Mountains wear good walking boots and warm clothes as you will be faced with a treacherous climb to a disappointing cascade of water! The price of the guide is additional and should be negotiated before setting off.  The peaceful haven in this bustling city is the El Badi Palace - well worth a visit.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: Finding a central hotel with good facilities in Marrakech with consistently good reviews on Trip Advisor wasn't easy so when we arrived at Les Jardins de La Koutoubia we were absolutely delighted and relieved that our homework had paid off.    The hotel is a wonderful oasis of calm ideally situated just a couple of minutes stroll around the corner from the commotion and chaos of Place Jemaa el Fna and the souks. I would not like to stay further away from the square - especially when it's hotter in the summer - as it's quite a walk to the square from some of the hotels we saw in the new town and getting taxis can be such a chore.    We found all the staff extremely friendly and helpful although we wish we'd brushed up on our French to make life easier throughout our visit to Marrakech. The hotel facilities were good although I would have preferred the pools to have been heated. There was free internet access in the basement and a shop off the reception selling souveniers postcards (plus stamps) and international newspapers plus an ATM cash machine. Next time this shop will definitely be my first stop on arrival in the hotel in order to buy something before heading out into the city just to get some small change which is extremely useful but can be difficult to come by.    It was fantastic having the Piano Bar to relax in before and after dinner (nice touch to give complementary nuts and olives and the Koutoubia Cocktail was scrummy!) and all the food we had in the hotel's restaurants was delicious. We dined in all of them except Le Relais De Paris which looks wonderful from the roof of the hotel looking down into the restaurant garden with the pool and huge mirror but it's just around the corner in an alley which put us off a bit - to be fair the alley is fully lit and has security guards on duty we just ran out of time to go there.    The Les Jardins de La Koutoubia hotel is very photogenic and restful - lighting is everything - there is even plenty of seating indoors if it's too hot or raining. Check out the Moroccan chap in the blue outfit who sits by the fireplace in the evening rotating his fez to make that wierd noise whilst playing the guitar. The vases of roses and displays of rose petals (including on the sinks in the washrooms) add to the magic.    For me the highlight of our stay in the hotel was having a his and hers hammam in the spa followed by his and hers Moroccan Massage - absolutely the best massage I've ever had - an experience I shall never forget in a hotel I will remember with great affection.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: A lovely hotel admist the madness of old Marrakech and one which provides an oasis after the hustle and bustle of the city. With a variety of resturants and it's excellent spa visitors can indulge themselves in the chaos of the souks/medina as much/little as they wish knowing that there is the "safety net" of this retreat never too far away.  If one really must stay in the old part of the city I would whole-heartedly recommend this hotel.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: The hotel was 5/5 for location 30 second walk from Jemma El F'na Square and once in the hotel its peaceful and calm. We went out of season so the hotel lacked atmosphere due to it being so quiet. The staff had very poor English so we struggled with the little French we knew thats not really a critisism just advise. The breakfast was awful the one dodgy toaster didnt brown the bread and the Q for eggs was so long it wasnt worth the wait. The rooms got cleaned about 4pm daily which was always the time we were in there. The Clarins spa was nice and peaceful but again even though the surroundings were plush the hotel lacked atmosphere - it was deadly quiet and staff behaved like robots. We didnt feel like we'd had a 5 star stay and would advise going to a hotel in Hivernage for 5 Star luxury.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: This is a lovely hotel in a great location. Just a few minues from the main square and an oasis of calm.    The main rooms are very nice. Service is sometimes a bit slow and haphazard (it can take several requests to get a full place laid forbreakfast) but always friendly and polite.    The only complaint from us was the bedroom. We had a standard room which was dark and cramped and we never got the air con to work properly. Even though we were there in January the room was constantly too hot. However the rooms were always absolutely clean.    Use this hotel but pay extra and get a better room
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Date: R E wrote a review Nov 2007
Review_Text: We booked this hotel because of the location as recommended here but we were slightly apprehensive due to some of the negative reviews. Our experience was excellent. From the moment we arrived every member of staff was warm and helpful from the guy that cleans the pool to the receptionists. Our room was spotless with rose petals arranged in the bathroom and the bedroom on arrival. We ate in three of the hotel restaurants all of which were great and the piano bar is terrific. There is a central swimming pool surrounded by a courtyard off of which are some 'random' soft furnished rooms where it's possible to escape with a book if you want to. At one end of the courtyard is an open area where you can sit and in the evenings this had a roaring log fire - the most romantic of settings.The location as mentioned before is perfect. Turn left and in two minutes you are at the Jeema square or turn right and in one minute you are on avenue Mohammed V. Yet despite this when you come back to the hotel you are into an oasis of calm. The spa area is first class with a large pool and many treatment rooms if you are into that. The hotel definitely has a Moroccan feel to it and I would certainly stay here again.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: what a setting- after a busy day in the souks or sightseeing you walk through the doors of the hotel and enter another place! the hotel was really clean the staff were helpful and the room was airy and spacious. The breakfast were good with plenty to choose from and eat. We also ate in the hotel restaraunts which were equally as good.A lovely way to see Marrakech experience the local life and then end the day with a swim and a relax definately go again and would recommend to anyone.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Title: Nice place for a romantic break
Review_Text: We spent 2 nights here after a week's 4x4 safari and it was a real treat didn't seem to be many people staying when we were there. Our room was the most basic one so it was small but beautifully furnished. From a design perspective this hotel is beautiful and furnished well it looks wonderful at night. We found the staff helpful and the food was very nice especially the Indian restaurant. It wasn't as expensive as we thought it would be. The spa is gorgeous especially the pool and the treatments are all Clarins. They are having some work done to extend it at the moment. As other reviews mention you really can't knock the location (but be prepared for the early wake up calls from the mosque - no need for an alarm!) All in all a lovely place to explore Marrakech from.

This is a little peace of tranquil paradise in the midst of chaotic Marrakech - beautiful leafy landscaping frames the pool and the rooms are spacious beautiful and opulent.    Check out the spa too - fabulous internal pool and great spa menu.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: Have just returned from a 4 night stay at this hotel and have very mixed feelings about the place.    We had a mini suite (room 170) and it was lovely having a seperate sitting room and further seating area on a balcony which overlooked a small pool ( didnt go in it as it was so dirty) a bathroom so big that you could have a party in it 2 40inch flat screen tvs complimentary fruit basket water and toiletries    The down side is the sheer lack of service we had to wait upon arrival almost 3 hours because our room hadnt been serviced the breakfast lacks variety bread always stale coffee always cold.    Although the hotel has 4 restaurants their menus are bland the staff on the reception area are constantly overcharging we were overcharged on 2 occasions for room service and bar bills and on departure having settled our final bill the previous day they tried to charge us again and became very rude and intimidating with no offer of an apology    Although the hotel is a delight to look at especially at night when it turns into a fairy tale setting with all the lanterns it lacks atmosphere being very morose and sombre.    I certainly will not be returning to Marrakech (hated it) but if you put this hotel in another city not sure if I would book again
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: Just returned on Saturday from Marrakech after a really relaxing 5 night break at Le Jardins de La Koutoubia. The location cannot be faulted just yards away from the square and everything that goes with it !! Our mini suite - room number 50 - was superb. This was on the ground floor and tucked away into a corner looking out on to a small patio area and only steps away from the exclusive pool for that area. The main pool is lovely but we preferred the quiet of the pool beside the room infact we were usually the only people in it. The terrace for the room was a welcome retreat from the hustle and bustle of the square and furnished with a group of comfy chairs looking on to the Koutoubia minaret....no need to set your alarm for an early wake up call !!! We enjoyed the food and ate in each restaraunt - the indian on the roof terrace was excellent as was the morrocan french and the international which we ate in twice. We also had the Hamman which was good the spa is undergoing some work at the present which will extend it quite a bit. the pool in the spa is stunning and very relaxing. I also had a massage which again was excellent. We have now been to Marrakech twice and cannot wait to go back. All in all an excellent time was had.

Review_Title: If not a Riad then has to be here...
Review_Text: As mentioned previously the location simply cannot be beaten and was a welcome refuge at the end of each day exploring the sites sounds and smells of Marrakkech. Service was mixed but overall pretty decent - a few room service orders got mixed up but always delivered with a smile. Pool and spa were great although they could do with cranking up the air conditioning in the gym. Room was fairly ordinary but comfortable enough. Biggest complaint was the noise. I was on the second floor but the noise from upstairs was ridiculously loud. I think the hotel perhaps hasn't been built as solidly as one would expect. Food decent enough and I thought reasonably priced. Would stay here again.

Review_Date: Jon S wrote a review Jul 2007
Review_Text: Superb location - Jemma El Fna is literally 2mins walk. We could see the Koutoubia minaret from our balcony.    Hotel was excellent. Service very helpful room clean and very tastefully decorated. Food in the restuarants was good although expensive. That is to be expected really considering the location.    Facilities in the hotel wer good the pool and roof terraces gardens and lobby were all well maintained and attractive. For me though the main draw was how close to all the action we were.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: This hotel is great. My wife and I stayed for x 4 nights from 5th July 2007. We had a standard room and just relaxed by the pool in the main. The hotel arranged our collection from the airport (200 DIH each way for x 2 passengers) this is about £12GBP each direction. Frankly this is a bargain as I for one can't be bothered with haggling with a taxi driver after a flight. We had no issues with the accommodation or staff. Our room was a standard double a mini suite would be nice but our room overlooked the main courtyard which contains the excellent swimming pool and sun loungers. Be quick to grab a sun lounger in the morning (I would recommend those closest to reception on the restaurant side for the longest afternoon sun) as there can be a shortage of beds depending on occupancy levels.  The hotel is the process of building a roof top pool this I think would be ready mid August 2007. This will be a great addition as there will be "longer" sun until perhaps 7pm. This new roof pool by the excellent Indian restaurant will increase the number of pools to x 4 the people from Clarins are a bit stuffy about using the one in the spa unless you have a treatment but you can "blag" your way in for a quick dip. Food is great in the hotel not overly expensive breakfast is of good quality and an outdoor table adds to the occasion. I would recommed eating out on at least a few occasions. We ate at La Foundouk (get a roof terrace table) and Da Moha (get a poolside table). Both offer good food and service / atmosphere.  The only sites we saw where: 1) Jemaa el Fna square which incidentally is about 3 minutes on foot from the hotels front door and 2) Majorelle Gardens about a 10 min taxi - do not pay more than 20 DIH each way for x 2 passengers.  The worst thing about this holiday was the air line - Altas Blue. Make sure you eat well before getting on the catering is a joke and needs to be paid for.  Book this property - it is great for an romantic "get away" - I did not see one resident under 20 year of age so no kids to wind you up and ruin the relaxation.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: quite the best locationamazing that a doorway leads from such chaosnoise smells& scruffiness into such an oasis of civilisation and calm and tranquility (well nearly ) great undergound spa  Our small room (218)was on 2nd floor and overlooked the pool however we were under the restaurant and could hear people walking around above us and moving chairs etc.  The only down side was that our travel agent did not tell us that the 3rd floor terrace is being rebuiltthere is a pool up there that in basically out of action as is a storage area for builders rubblethe walkway is an obstacle course of cement pools and hosesthe lift is used by the builders to transport their materials.We sat by the downstairs pool to the dulsit tones of hammersdrills and grinders.Check this out before you go it spoilt our relaxing time by the pool.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: Ok it is not a riad however is a very good hotel. We spent 5 nights during Easter period. No issues about services: the staff was always very helpful and prompt. Very clean and huge room. We got a new patio room looking at a new courtyard (by the way very nice). The room (n.156) was very roomy clean with a flat screen TV huge bathroom and a wonderful terrace (I would say the best one of the hotel). Only issue is the noise from the hallway and the from the stairs which are close to the room. The hotel s really an oasis in the chaos of the medina. It is a few steps from the place Jemaa el F'naa (this is really a bizarre place) however when you enter in the hotel you find calm and peace. The pool is nice with many sunbeds (please don't take places hours in advance with towels it's a shame!); the water is very cold! We took dinner 3 times in hotel in different restaurants (Moroccan Indian grill): quality service choice very good. Prices quite above average. If back to Marrakech I would try to stay in a riad (payoing attention to the selection in term of quality and location) however this hotel in a very good choice as price quality location (that cannot be better!). Reccommended.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with family

Review_Text: As others have said the hotel is very conveniently placed for pretty much everything. The entrance hall with view of pool is attractive and they give you mint tea on arrival. Our "patio" rooms were spacious with good bathrooms and a very small terrace overlooking a formal garden. However we had booked a twin and a double and got two doubles. No twins available so our grown-up daughter slept in the smallish double and our 6 ft son slept three nights on the sofa. Reception staff were unhelpful and disinterested and said we would have to take it up with our travel agent on return. The way they dealt with other issues left a lot to be desired as well - more training needed. Everywhere very clean and fragrant. Lots of flowers.    Breakfast pretty good with efficient service. Didn't try dinner.    The pool is very attractive but quite cold and there aren't enough sunbeds so we never sat on one. This happens in so many hotels. Pools should be a pleasant temperature with plenty of sunbeds. I only saw one person swim. However they have very nearly completed a roof top swimming pool and deck area which will be fabulous and we sat up there - very few guests knew it was there so we had it almost to ourselves.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with family

Review_Text: This is a modern hotel just a 2minute walk from the Djem al fna and as such is ideally located for the main attractions (and handy should you need to nip back to your room promptly!)  We found the reception staff to be friendly fluent in several languages and even negotiated a discount price with a free upgrade to a suite. The suite had a large bathroom (the bath was great) huge bed (very very hard) sitting room two plasma screens (though rubbish TV) and a generous balcony overlooking a verdant courtyard; quite a contrast to life on the other side of the hotel wall.  The suite was situated in the new extension but bizzarely it took three seprate lifts to reach it.  The reception area is the older part of the hotel and it opens out on to courtyard with fairly large pool and sun loungers. The piano bar is close by and is the ideal accompaniment to a very civilised poolside G&T.  We did not try the food as the menu looked unpromising and there was plenty of good dining to be had in Marrakech anyway.  The clientel were as expected largely european well heeled and generally middle aged or older though there were one or two younger families.  This hotel is a great sanctuary from the hussle and bustle the heat the smell and so on but doesn't feel at all Moroccan - like many such hotels it could be anywhere.  On the whole I enjoyed my stay here (3 nights) because it was comfortable BUT... the over-riding impression was that this was not a 5 star hotel. I wonder whose star ratings we're talking about. There were minor issues such as dud light bulbs plaster smears not cleaned off bathroom tiles and my pet hate - the room maid knocking you up at 9.15am and actually coming into the room (happened twice) whilst I'm not suitably attired to receive guests!!! The bill also contained an entry for the minibar which we had not used. These minor points could be so easily rectified but personally I would rate the hotel as 4 star.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: The location of the hotel simply cant be faulted. Its very close (five minutes walk) to the centre of the old town and therefore everything that is good about Marrakech.    We had asked the hotel to provide transport from the airport to the hotel - this was perfect and at only £6 per person each way not too expensive. The public areas of the hotel are excellent - the pool in the central couryard very picturesque the piano bar good the new spa facilities also excellent and well priced. The public areas all round very good with lots of places to sit.    The breakfasts were very good with opportuniity to eat outside around the pool which was very nice. We didnt sample any of the other food but there is a snack bar and resturant at the hotel which both looked perfectly fine - there is too much to choose from in the old town.    The rooms are medium size comfortable and fine rather than particularly special. The bathrooms are average. The more expensive patio rooms have a view (only if you stand up!) but there is no verandah or access outside. The rooms are spotlessly clean. Parts of the hotel we obviously being upgraded (bit noisy) - in particular some of the rooms and the rooftop which will improve the hotel further.    The attitude of the staff lets the place down (as noted in other reviews). Service was slow both at reception and in the bar (which is also quite expensive). rather annmoyingly my wife was refused a table to eat on her own one lunchtime at the snack bar around the pool (there were free tables). Checking out was a challenge as the receptionist was trying to do several things at once.    All in all a really nice visit fantastic location fantastic public areas but let down rather by the service - but would stay again
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with friends

Review_Title: Great hotel in the BEST location in Marrakech
Review_Text: We stayed here for 5 nights in February and were delighted with everything. To start with our room on the first floor was HUGE - I think perhaps it was a 'mini suite' although we had only paid for a standar room. It had 2 toilets and 2 bathrooms and a large lounge area with big plasma TV (which actually spoiled the look somewhat). It overlooked the small street outside but that didn't matter - the rooms that overlooked the pool would not have been worth the upgrade.The best thing about it was the location - 3 minute easy walk from all the action in the Djemma el Fna square. It was such a nice place to come back to after all the hustle and bustle. The inner courtyard with huge swimming pool and surrounding open lounges was beautiful and fairly quiet. We met other people who were staying in Riyads/Dars in the medina but they did not have the pool and other facilities that we had (2 restaurants piano bar for cocktails before eating out in the vening/brandies and coffee on our return hamman/spa) We also met a couple who were staying in a modern hotel in the new town and spent all their time going backwards and forwards in petit taxi to the square - what a waste of time (and money). We ate in the hotel one night and the food was excellent. We had lunch there in the courtyard almost every day. I think it was good value for money and would stay there again - the photos you see of the small boutique riyads look inviting but I think we made the best choice.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Title: what were Conde Naste thinking of?
Review_Text: Let's get one thing straight: this is not a 5-star hotel. The walls are too thin for a 5-star and the whole place generally too clattery and noisy. If the telly is on in the next room you can hear it clearly; likewise if someone has a hacking cough in the room above - as was the case during our stay. So goodness knows what Conde Nast Traveller were doing when they put it in their 100 best hotels of all time. I wonder about CN I really do. They claim their reviewers never accept freebies but it baffles me how some of their "top" hotels get onto their list.    The Koutoubia is a good 4-star. The common parts (except for the gloomy dusty lobbty) are lovely. The pool area is most chic and there's a lovely shady sitting out area at the end with huge sofas and rugs. All very Moroccan. Also the downstairs Moroccan restaurant was great. Food nothing special but fantastic ambiance as one lounged away on cushions feeling like a vizier or whatever they are in Morocco.    The place falls down with the rooms. Ours was distinctly faded and past its best with scuffed basic G-plan style furniture that probably wasn't that great when it was new. The bed was comfortable but the walls were marked and the plaster chipped. You get the feeling that the management are getting enough package tourists and that they couldn't care if it's all a bit rundown. Sad really.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: We had an excellent experience with this hotel.    Firstly we were upgraded to a superb first-floor room which was rather spacious for a riad-style room with sliding doors opening out to face the pool and sun streaming in all afternoon.    We found the hotel staff to be friendly professional and very helpful. We had none of the poor service mentioned by other review writers.    The facilities were very good - there is an excellent indoor pool and spa area lovely large heated outdoor pool (which you could lie next to on the loungers in the sun all day as people were doing - in January!)  and two good restaurants (both quite well rated by the boutique travel guide we were using).    The breakfast was fine fairly typical for a hotel of this level but nothing special.    The hotel is located right next to the bustling Medina but within the hotels walls is a tranquil oasis - we were even woken in the morning by birds singing within the large hotel courtyard which was a delight! And also by the wailing of the Muslim prayers from the nearby Koutoubia mosque but we found this to be a positive feature rather than a problem.    Overall we thought this hotel was great - you could enjoy several days here without even leaving as the hotel is so well-equipped but partly also because quite frankly there isn't that much decent sight-seeing to do within Marrakech itself.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: I'll start by saying we didn't stay there - but we did go there for lunch based.    The hotel itself is very lavish with a pool around which the hotel is centred. The reception is very spacious but there seemed to be no staff around to point you in the direction of the restaurant and no one on reception seemed to acknowledge our presence. As a result we wandered around until we found it ourselves - and then stood there at the entrance waiting for a staff member to seat us - we were studiously ignored until we started to make for a table ourselves. At that point we were placed behind a tree - so we had the pleasure of watching staff take the orders and serve people who arrived well after us    The food itself was nothing to write home about - the lunchtime snack menu of any European hotel would not be very much different. Burgers with fries salad steak - that sort of thing. When it did turn up it was passable - but by that point we just wanted to leave - two and a half hours to serve a salad starter and two mains with beer and water...    We weren't dressed like backpackers (not that that should diminish the service received) in fact we were better dressed than some of the residents - but from the off the staff's attitude was wrong and everything they did for us was a inconvenience to them.    For a place for lunch I would suggest the newly opened (in the past 4 months) Villa Flore off Rue Sidi Al Yamani for laid back chic and fine dining - along with the best and coldest bottle of Heineken one could ever want – I don’t think it touched the sides!    At the metal workers market near the Badii Palace – try Kozybar – a Moroccan fusion bar/restaurant. During the day it does slightly Moroccan food – if you call Kebab and Fries traditional! With modern Arabic dance music belting out - during the day it’s a place to sit back and soak up the sun in summer – or huddle round the fires inside in winter as we did on this visit. With wine at about 130Dh a bottle it’s cheaper than 3 beers. In the evening the menu changes to Moroccan/French cuisine with the added bonus that the chef is Japanese and does massive sushi platters. The music comes from a live band sat around the baby grand on the ground floor. A good range of cigars too.    Also try Kechmara in the Gueliz – a retro style bar that does a good set menu of the day for 150Dh (about 10GBP). Hang out and watch ex-pat fashionistas socialise – all very interesting!

Review_Title: Oasis in the middle of Marrakech
Review_Text: Hotel is in a great location but close to the central mosque so expect an early wake up call!    We had a patio room overlooking the pool which we thought was 5* quality and nicely furnished. Ziad on reception was also particularly friendly and helpful in booking restaurants.etc    On the down side the breakfast in the morning was a bun fight and the hotel is a little impersonal in a city known for it's boutique hotels
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Title: Overrated Les Jardins de la Koutoubia
Review_Text: This hotel is 5 star and is quoted from Conde Naste traveller as one of the top 100 hotels in the world - don't know when they visited but the coffee and breakfast are terrible the rooms scruffy the menu lists rather limited and the staff forgetful.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: It is the first impressions that can leave a nasty tast in your mouth. We were not collected from the airport and had to pay around £12.00 When I told the receptionist she couldn't care less. Then we we out in a room with a small double bed and I had specifically requested 2 beds. The rest of our stay was ok. Bathrooms tiny and aircon not very good. A few things not working in the room but they did sort them out. Generall the staff were very pleasant except the chef in the morning who thought she was terribly important. I could have left feeling it was ok but then we were overcharged by one night when we checked out and they would not let us leave until we paid it even though I had confirmation that I had paid the travel agency. I left with a very unhappy feeling about my trip and it was all down to the Manager and receptions attitude. Would never return there
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled with friends

Review_Text: I read all the tripadvisor reviews before choosing this hotel. Knowing that I was travelling to a Moslem country I was expecting to hear the call to prayer and cannot understand why other travellers should be surprised or disturbed by it. I think I heard it twice at night in our whole stay and only because I was wakeful.  I found the hotel to be an oasis within the heat and noise of Marrakech. We actually booked a medina room but were upgraded to a poolside room on arrival. Friends with a medina room were equally content and enjoyed having a view of the Koutoubia mosque. Looking at the floor plans we discovered that all the rooms are different sizes because of the shape of the building. Some pool view rooms are the same size as those facing the medina  We enjoyed eating at the hotel on several occasions during our 10 night stay. The poolside Imlil snack bar was good value and the salads were superb. Koutoubia restaurant and Les Terrasses were both good but prices are more at UK levels and therefore not cheap by Moroccan standards.  Service was exemplary both on poolside and in the hotel. We built up an excellent relationship with staff and learned a lot about them. They worked exceptionally hard to keep the hotel immaculate.  I have some minor criticisms I think the management need to address. The maitres d'hotel need to keep a more vigilant eye on the breakfast buffet and think ahead. Things quite often run out and guests are left waiting for the plates/bowls to be replenished especially if they arrive towards the end of breakfast.  My other criticism is that there is no inventory in the minibar. Keep a very close eye on what is in there and what you have or ask the hotel staff to provide an inventory at the start of your stay. They need to be more organised about this.  Pool decor. lighting and food were great with relaxed but professional service. Air conditioning and ceiling fan combined to cope well with 40+ degrees. Nobody could have expected more.  I would definitely stay again.
Reviewer_Trip_Type: Trip type: Traveled as a couple

Review_Text: This hotel is in a fantastic location very lively and 2 min walk to Souks however it could be so much more if the staff were friendlier. Although the pool is amazing and surrounding rooms are decorated in decadent Moroccan style and look faboulous it is all a bit musty and old looking maybe due to August heat but you feel slightly uncomfortable due to lack of friendliness from staff. One recepetionist just bordered on plain rude however the 2nd girl in afternoon's was absolutely charming but we didn't find them particularly friendly although the smile is on the face you can see they are completely disinterested. However cleanliness was good and rooms always kept immaculate even though air conditioning is not great very poor and rooms smelt slightly old and musty. Would recomend you take a guide first time into Souk as it is all a bit of a culture shock but a great way to get to know the right price to pay and the guide will advise you on fair and honest price. The Moroccan people were charming and very polite in Souks although bit pushy but amazing place to see however the difference between 5 star hotel and poverty outside hotel door did not sit comfortably with me. Great stylish restaurants are: Le Comptoir & Le Foundouk (most romantic) cost about £50 for 2 for meal with drinks only not a bottle of wine. Most other restaurants closed in August so beware if you are going for food. Ps: French only spoken not English but if you try to speak in Arabic they are much more friendlier.

Review_Title: Great location and a relaxing haven
Review_Text: We stayed at the hotel for a long weekend in February and had a fantastic time    The location is fabulous and I doubt that any other hotel in the city could rival it on this score. It is literally a two minute walk from the bustling and atmospheric main square.    The decor of the hotel is contemporary with lots of Morroccan influence and is spotlessly clean. Our room had a "medina" view which was great for watching the world go by outside. We couldn't believe our luck when we got to our room and we had two bathrooms - one each!!  The swimming pool area is stunning and the bar provides a relaxing retreat after a busy afternoon round the souks!    The staff are very helpful and attentive and we found that they couldn't do enough for us.    There are three restaurants in the hotel. We ate in two of them and the food was very good however we would recommend going out in the city for dinner just to experience the atmosphere of Marrakesh.    We had a guide for an afternoon which we would definitely recommend. The souks really are a rabbit warren of alley ways and as a tourist I doubt we would have ventured to some of the workshops that he took us to which were hugely interesting. Of course you get taken to some shops that the tour company obviously work with but there was no hard sell and lots of free mint tea - a small price to pay for what was an enjoyable afternoon overall!

Review_Title: Good Hotel in a great location.
Review_Text: I can't understand the comments of the previous reviewer as my Wife and I were there on the date of his review. Great location on the edge of the Medina. The street noise never bothered us -however the summons to prayer from the Mosques was somewhat intrusive at five in the morning. Our standard room was spotlessly clean and everything worked although I agree that the bath took a long time to fill.  We ate in twice - food fine served by courteous and friendly staff.  The only real problem was with reception. We asked them to book at a nearby restaurant which turned out to be fully booked. They never told us and we had to make an embarrassing withdrawal from the restaurant. Overall a very good hotel in a great position and a welcome oasis away from the city.

Review_Date: Iain O wrote a review Mar 2006
Review_Text: My wife and I stayed here for 2 nights in March 2006. We were booked for 7 nights but had to return home early due to my wife taking ill (no fault of the hotel or Morocco).    We were slightly disappointed with the hotel which was descibed as 5 star.    The location is superb: on the edge of the Medina 2 minute walk to the Djemaa el Fna square 5 minutes to the souks.    Rooms (we had a patio room) were good although we insisted on changing ours as the first was on an inside corner and felt overlooked by the adjacent family room with a balcony which was at right angles to us. The room we moved to (same floor) was very different and included a small lounge area. The cleanliness and standard of housekeeping was superb.    Our room was very noisy. On the first (Sunday) evening some residents were up late in the courtyard (patio) and it sounded as if they were in the room with us. This went on into the wee small hours. Prayers were called at the nearby Koutoubia Mosque at 5am and there is NO WAY that you will sleep through that!    The breakfast buffet could only be described as mediocre.  Our two dinner experiences were OK but not special. Service was good but the food quality was not great.    Advice on currency: the exchange rate is the same everywhere (airport bank hotel). It's easy to change currency whenever you land at Marrakech airport but I didn't ask for a lot of small (20 & 50 dirham) notes. This then caused problems as you need to tip often. The hotel couldn't help so I headed for the bank - no problem.    Purely a personal preference but if we return to Marrakech after our abbreviated first stay I think we would try different accommodation possibly a ryad.

The only possitive thing to be said is that the hotel is ideally located for a visit to the old city. It was probably an excellent hotel many years ago but now has had its best times.  We stayed for 3 nights and could not sleep because of the temperature and noise : the airco did not work: "would be fixed the next day" or " did not work because the majority of guests did not ask for". When we opened the window we had all night long the street noises below. The toilet flush dit not work and it took 3/4 of an hour to fill the bad. You could not get into the bathroom with two people at once and the bedroom was hardly bigger. So if you stay at this hotel never take the front rooms but opt for the more expensive inner rooms (if available). For us there was no possibility for upgrading because "this was the room that was booked" period. Useless to say that service is less than poor: it's arrogant and unfriendly.  Meals are moderate and we cannot understand the possitive reviews in this respect.

Like the other reviews posted for this hotel we have to agree and say that this hotel is truly wonderful. We stayed for a week in July 2005 (very very hot!) for a short honeymoon break right after our wedding and because we were honeymooners they gave us a complimentary upgrade to a large room overlooking the pool/courtyard plus a lovely fruit basket to welcome gift.    The service throughout the hotel was great the pool was a calm oasis in the scorching heat and our room was always spotless (everyday the cleaners even came up with a new design for rose petals on our bed!) now that's what you can attention to detail! The food in the hotel was great value and really good but the best bit is that the hotel was literally round the corner from the main square and all the souks.    We had a really relaxing and enjoyable stay here a wonderful way to start married life and we have no hesitation recommending it to everyone. If only all hotels could be as pleasant......

Review_Title: Not the best - in fact the worst for service
Review_Text: The hotel is beautifully designed but that is the only positive thing I can say about it.  I stayed at the hotel for 3 nights over the New Year.  The food was poor. Our room was missing several important facilities - a phone that worked bath robes hair dryer and a safe. Several rooms are next to a building site and building works starts early with a lot of loud machinery which is disturbing to guests.    The staff were unhelpful and not respectful to women.  My expensive camera was stolen from the hotel on New Year's Day morning from our dinner table (having spent £300 for tickets to the evening's entertainment) but the hotel made no effort for me to retrieve it or even bother to find out the model of the camera or where it had last been seen. I had to demand that they called the police and there was no follow up from staff. It could have been handled 100% better if they had tried to be helpful. Unfortunately the Manager of this hotel shrugged his shoulders and walked away when I tried to ask for help.    This is an pricey 5 star hotel but I believe the service is more like 2 star which is a great shame as it could have been a much better experience.

We have recently returned from 7 days at this hotel and were extremely impressed. It is a calm oasis in the midst of the bedlam that characterises Marrakech. Situated only two minutes away from the Koutoubia mosque and the Square it is ideally placed to explore the city. However this central location means that you are woken in the early hours by the first call to prayer from the mosque!  The rooms are spacious and very well serviced and ours had a great view of the pool. The hotel is set around a courtyard with lovely chill-out rooms surrounding the pool. You can sit around a blazing fire in the winter having a drink taking in the view or there is a piano bar and two restaurants. Whilst the restaurants are very nice we prefered to dine out because there is a huge choice of great restaurants. Our favourites included: Le Pavillion Lolo Quoi and Al Fassia. The hotel staff are friendly and very helpful and overall we were very happy.

An absolutely stunning hotel. A great place to stay if you're looking for culture. The rooms are amazing and on the whole the hotel is very beautiful. Not a place for families nothing for children to do and no entertainment. It's just a heavenly retreat
